channel.title: Building a computer
channel.description:
I have no knowledge in the field, so explanations are appreciated.
I'm looking to build a desktop that will be used for web/server software, and occasionally playing games. I hope to support at least 3 monitors, but if the card supports more - I'll probably buy them. I am not looking for anything fancy. It doesn't have to be the best of the best, or support 1080p on max games - because I'm not a heavy pc gamer, but I do play occasionally.
The build itself:
Case: Something big enough to house everything + cooling / whatever is needed. Doesn't have to be pretty. CPU: No idea how to explain this because I don't know whether I need multiple cores/processing speed etc. Motherboard: I'm not really sure, because I don't know enough about computing. GPU: Multiple monitor support, good memory, something that will last me a good bit of time. RAM: Not really sure how much I'll need, but let's just go with 8GB for safe measures. HDD or SSD: Whichever is best, looking to have at least 1-2TB though. PSU: No idea what this is needed for, too lazy to do research. But if I need it, make it decent.
Monitors, mouse, keyboard, and other shit will not be included in the build price.
I do not have a budget, but I do not need a super computer. Just something to last me a few years for business, school, and fun.
Used for: Web design, hosting, file storage, graphics, video, and audio editing/storage. I'm looking to further my knowledge in programming/web design - so I'll be hosting everything myself. I want to be able to run all the software side-by-side without freezing. I mainly do video/audio editing on my mac, but I would like the desktop to function as well. I'd also like this to be able to excel in running things like cinema and adobe suite.
any help is appreciated.

item.title: Building a computer
item.dc:creator: @Vain1 Vain_
item.description:
@Vain1 wrote:

I’m not too much of a hard core gamer. mostly just emulators of consoles games, minecraft, and some other standalone games.

item.title: Building a computer
item.dc:creator: @The_Web_Guy The Web Guy
item.description:
@The_Web_Guy wrote:

I don’t know about cases/motherboards/cooling and what not. But for newer games you usually need at least 3gb RAM (older games from '08-'10 use ~2gb RAM) processor wise, I would recommend a decent speed quad core. (at least 2.4GHz). Video card should have at least 1gb allocated.

Read full topic

item.title: Building a computer
item.dc:creator: @tL tL
item.description:
@tL wrote:

Vain_:

what do you mean tL? are there much better options for the price?

Just the talk of 512MB GDDR3 GPUs. Pretty much everything except the lowest end stuff will have 1024MB GDDR5 these days.

item.dc:creator: @Vain1 Vain_
item.description:
@Vain1 wrote:

I don’t see myself using the software too heavily, because I can still do it on my Mac. I would just like the ability to do so if wanted. I’m currently stuck with a half broken acer laptop from 2009, and a MacBook. so hoping to make a desktop that will last me a few years.

Read full topic

item.title: Building a computer
item.dc:creator: @lothy Lothy
item.description:
@lothy wrote:

If it’s a development machine then you’ll probably want to run virtual machines at some point.
Go 16GB RAM minimum if you see yourself doing that.

Read full topic

item.title: Building a computer
item.dc:creator: @Loveandpower Loveandpower
item.description:
@Loveandpower wrote:

[quote=“SilentCJ, post:20, topic:542382”][quote author=Vain_ link=topic=661260.msg4420394#msg4420394 date=1398107119]
I don’t want it to be a full time web server. sort of like wamp, but I want to incorporate other stacks to further my knowledge as be able to test things etc. I don’t want to stick to php and javascript.

it’s mostly going to be for visual effects (video editing/photo manipulation) and audial modifications.
[/quote]
and popping in an extra 8GB of RAM.[/quote]I doubt he will ever use 16GB …his HD would start to slow down before that happened. I can state that from personal experience. The only time you need 16GB/32GB/64GB/128GB ( who the hell has 128GB of memory…good lord the heat… ) would be for video editors, web designers, and the such.

As he isn’t doing this on a professional level I doubt he would need THAT much but that’s just my two cents. Unless he plans to hardcore visual studios etc.

Read full topic

item.title: Building a computer
item.dc:creator: @SilentCJ SilentCJ
item.description:
@SilentCJ wrote:

[quote=“Vain_, post:19, topic:542382”]I don’t want it to be a full time web server. sort of like wamp, but I want to incorporate other stacks to further my knowledge as be able to test things etc. I don’t want to stick to php and javascript.

it’s mostly going to be for visual effects (video editing/photo manipulation) and audial modifications.[/quote]
Ah okay that’s fair enough, so more of a development server rather than production?

Either way, if you’re going for video editing etc the above build will suffice, possibly consider upgrading the graphics card to a GTX 770/780 and popping in an extra 8GB of RAM.

Read full topic

item.title: Building a computer
item.dc:creator: @SilentCJ SilentCJ
item.description:
@SilentCJ wrote:

You may want to rethink what you’re actually doing though, you want to use it to host servers, yet also want it to be a powerhouse (think of the power usage!)? Shouldn’t do both, either buy a dedicated system or host it using a third party, it’ll work out cheaper in the long run.

I can personally recommend a HP N54L microserver. Bought it for £100 and kitted it out with some hard drives and 8gb RAM, it’s a monster now

Read full topic

item.title: Building a computer
item.dc:creator: @SilentCJ SilentCJ
item.description:
@SilentCJ wrote:

This’ll handle anything you throw at it, though you should’ve specified a budget. The case was just generic, feel free to swap that out.

On top of that you’d need the OS, and an optical drive. I personally think in 2014 it’s pointless having an internal disc drive when I just use a single external USB drive (around £12) for about 5 of my PCs and laptops (on the extremely rare occasion that I actually need to use a CD/DVD).

http://uk.pcpartpicker.com/p/3vNyY

Read full topic

item.title: Building a computer
item.dc:creator: @tL tL
item.description:
@tL wrote:

[quote=“Muroth, post:2, topic:542382”]Case: I’d get something big enough to fit atleast 2 120mm fans. I have no clue about water-cooling, however I hear it’s very efficient. It doesn’t take up much space, but if you go that route look up compatible cases.

CPU: If you plan on doing heavy (1080p video that has 2+ hours of footage) multimedia work, i’d strongly recommend atleast a quad core else you’ll be waiting possibly days for it to process. I suggest an intel core, perhaps i5 or i7 or i3.

Motherboard: You want DDR3 RAM compatibility, a long with support for multiple cores, and the ability to add external cards (PCI/PCI-express)

GPU: Atleast 512MB DDR3 imo, hdmi/vga/dvi

RAM: Atleast 8GB DDR3

HDD/SDD: I use a 128GB SSD card for Windows itself, and a 1TB HDD for programs

PSU: I have a 500W, but I feel as if that’s cutting it short. I’d get atleast 750W but that’s just me.

If moderate gaming, light multimedia, then you can cut down on the specs. My first rig was AMD Dual core @ 8GB DDR3 @ 512MB DDR2 GPU and it had no lag when it came to games such as BF3 and COD:BO.

Note i’m no professional[/quote]

This was posted in 2014?

Read full topic

They have a compatibility section that should tell you if it should fit in your computer ( if you use one of their cases )

Another option is to use pcpartpicker and you can build it off of f there. Been trying to send you a private message but your inbox is always full…

item.title: Building a computer
item.dc:creator: @Muroth Muroth
item.description:
@Muroth wrote:

The heatsink is installed on top of the CPU itself. Usually it’ll have hooks that hook onto the CPU slot. Be sure your motherboard can support the type of CPU you’re going to get. From there, see which heatsinks are compatible with your socket type (Also located on motherboard specs.) If you need help, post which motherboard you’re interested in and I can explain further.

edit:
Rough summary of the parts you’ll be installing:

Optical drive (DVD tray) and floppy isn’t necessary

edit:edit:
http://electronics.howstuffworks.com/how-to-tech/build-a-computer1.htm

Read full topic

item.title: Building a computer
item.dc:creator: @Vain1 Vain_
item.description:
@Vain1 wrote:

and where exactly does the heatsink go? and how would I be able to tell whether all my stuff is compatible or not, before purchasing?

Read full topic

item.title: Building a computer
item.dc:creator: @Muroth Muroth
item.description:
@Muroth wrote:

There are 60mm,80mm,92mm, and 120mm sized fans. They’re just smaller/bigger size. You have the CPU fan(s) and the case fan(s). Case fans alone won’t do it, they just circulate the air. I have a combination of three case fans and one CPU fan, which keeps my temps at ~30C.

There are passive and active heatsinks. Passive is just the metal piece that dissipates the heat. Active includes a fan. Most custom rigs use active (passive + fan). A heatsink is usually included with the CPU. I bought an aftermarket heatsink and it came with an attachable fan (active). Just be sure you use thermal paste in between the two (IC Diamond is great IMO). The higher airflow the fan has the better it will cool.

No specific size, just as long as you have an intake and an exhaust.

edit: I’d do some research on how it all comes together just so you can get an idea of what you’re actually doing.

Read full topic

item.title: Building a computer
item.dc:creator: @Vain1 Vain_
item.description:
@Vain1 wrote:

would regular cooling be okay with my goals? like the heatsink and te few fans like you said?

are there any other methods of cooling, besides liquid? are there different types of heatsinks? is there a specific type of fan needed? are some better than others?

Read full topic

item.title: Building a computer
item.dc:creator: @Muroth Muroth
item.description:
@Muroth wrote:

pc case comes with hookups for power,reset,etc along with screws for mobo. psu plugs into motherboard. fans plug into motherboard. cpu has slot where you put it in. if not water cooling, get a heatsink and thermal paste. external gpu connects to pci-e/pci slots. just the basics. it’s not hard to put together it all, you’ll have no problem.

AMD is the cheaper option but still good. Intel is more expensive but is the better choice.

Read full topic
